title: Local File Disclosure on the █████ (https://████████.edu/) leads to the full source code disclosure and credentials leak
content:
Description
During poking around ██████.00/24 range - ██████████ looking for the Cisco devices, I came across ███ which resolved to the https://███████.edu/
While it's a not .mil host, it's likely related to the DoD since it hosted in the DoD-controlled ASN.
I discovered few critical vulnerabilities here, one of them is LFD (local file disclosure).
POC
https://██████.edu/file.ashx?path=web.config
will download the website configuration file.
It exposes the DB credentials:
███
Similarly, attacker able to get content of any server-side resource, such as source code of application:
https://███.edu/file.ashx?path=UserAccountJSON.aspx.cs
Impact
Source code & DB credentials leakage. Attacker can use it to compromise the resource.
steps: Navigate to the target URL: https://███████.edu/
Access the vulnerable endpoint by appending '/file.ashx?path=web.config' to the URL to retrieve the web.config file
Alternatively, access other server-side resources by modifying the 'path' parameter to target specific files, e.g., '/file.ashx?path=UserAccountJSON.aspx.cs'
vuln_description: The vulnerability is a Local File Disclosure (LFD) that allows an attacker to access sensitive server-side files, including configuration files and source code, by manipulating the 'path' parameter in the URL. This can lead to the exposure of database credentials and application logic.
reason: The attack is straightforward and does not involve multiple components or complex interactions. The vulnerability is discovered by simply manipulating a URL parameter, which is a common and well-known attack vector.
